newsitem.title: USA: ComEd Zion 2 nuke seen restarting mid-April.
newsitem.headline: ComEd Zion 2 nuke seen restarting mid-April.

text.p: Commonwealth Edison Co said Friday its 1,040 megawatt (MW) Zion 2 nuclear unit will likely restart in mid-April after shutting last September for refueling.
The adjacent unit 1, also rated at 1,040 MW and shut since Feb 21, will likely return to service in early May following surveillance testing, company spokesman Gary Wald said.
Following the outage, the unit is expected to operate around 40 percent power until it goes off line in September for refueling.
Both units are located in Zion, Ill.
Earlier this week, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) said it would meet with ComEd today to discuss improper procedures while Zion 1 was shutting down on Feb 21.
The NRC said three weeks of investigations began on Feb 25 over how a control room operator improperly moved control rods during the shutdown.
The NRC cited in a statement the apparent failure of management to review plant conditions before the rods were withdrawn by the operator.
ComEd was not immediately available for comment.
All four units at both the LaSalle and Zion nuclear plants were placed on the NRC's watchlist on Jan 29.

Separately, ComEd's 794 MW Dresden 3 unit is still scheduled to go off line March 30 for refueling, while the 789 MW Quad Cities 2 unit is still slated to restart in early May after shutting down March 1 for refueling.
ComEd is a subsidiary of Unicom Corp.
